eda_steps.step_description: Analysis of collision count distribution showing severe class imbalance with 95.2% no collisions, 4.6% single collision, and 0.2% double collisions.
step_insights: Severe class imbalance with 95.2% of records showing no collisions
Only 4.8% of records contain collision events (351 single, 15 double)
Imbalanced classification problem requiring specialized techniques

eda_steps.step_description: Assessment of data completeness across all features, identifying patterns and extent of missing data.
step_insights: 1,520 total missing values (1.53% of all data)
Most features missing 55 values (0.72%), except phone use with 1,025 missing (13.4%)
Missing data pattern suggests systematic collection issues rather than random missingness

eda_steps.step_description: Distribution analysis of key numerical telematic features showing variance and skewness patterns across driving behavior metrics.
step_insights: Miles driven shows highest variance (735K) with right-skewed distribution
Driving hours and miles are strongly correlated indicators of exposure
Most features are positively skewed requiring transformation for modeling

eda_steps.step_description: Analysis of categorical variables including month and driver_id, examining their distribution and potential impact on collision prediction.
step_insights: Monthly data fairly balanced across 12 months (550-680 records each)
Driver_id has 7,664 unique values indicating mostly unique drivers
Seasonal patterns may exist requiring temporal feature engineering

eda_steps.step_description: Correlation analysis revealing relationships between numerical features and their association with collision outcomes.
step_insights: Miles driven shows strongest correlation (0.297) with collision outcomes
Drive hours (0.295) and trip count (0.254) are next strongest predictors
Speed-related features show weaker correlations suggesting exposure more important than behavior

eda_steps.step_description: Identification of anomalous values using IQR method across numerical features to understand data quality and extreme cases.
step_insights: Time speeding has highest outlier rate (17%), indicating measurement issues
Driving behavior features (brakes, acceleration) have 12% outlier rates
Outliers may represent legitimate extreme driving patterns rather than errors

eda_steps.step_description: Box plot analysis showing how key driving features vary across collision count classes to identify discriminative patterns.
step_insights: Clear escalation in miles driven: 425 (no collision) → 1,294 (1 collision) → 3,445 (2 collisions)
Higher exposure (miles) strongly associated with increased collision risk
Risk follows exposure pattern rather than driving skill/behavior indicators

dataset_description: Telematic vehicle collision dataset with 7,667 driver-month records containing 10 numerical driving behavior features, 2 categorical features (driver_id, month), and collision count target. Data represents vehicle telematics collected for collision prediction modeling.

columns.name: driver_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each driver (7,664 unique values)
columns.additional_information: High-cardinality categorical identifier, not suitable as direct feature but could be used for grouping/stratification

columns.name: month
columns.description: Month of data collection (12 unique values from Jan-22 to Dec-22)
columns.additional_information: Temporal feature showing seasonal patterns, fairly balanced distribution across months

columns.name: count_trip
columns.description: Number of trips taken by driver in the month (1-31 trips)
columns.additional_information: Exposure metric with moderate correlation to collisions (0.254), 55 missing values

columns.name: miles
columns.description: Total miles driven in the month (0-14,903 miles)
columns.additional_information: Primary exposure metric, strongest collision predictor (0.297 correlation), highly right-skewed

columns.name: drive_hours
columns.description: Total driving hours in the month (0-615 hours)
columns.additional_information: Second strongest collision predictor (0.295), highly correlated with miles driven

columns.name: count_brakes
columns.description: Number of hard braking events (0-5,080 events)
columns.additional_information: Driving behavior metric with 0.251 collision correlation, 12% outlier rate

columns.name: count_accelarations
columns.description: Number of hard acceleration events (0-5,084 events)
columns.additional_information: Driving behavior metric with 0.251 collision correlation, similar distribution to braking

columns.name: time_speeding_hours
columns.additional_information: Low collision correlation (0.044), highest outlier rate (17%) suggesting data quality issues

columns.name: time_phoneuse_hours
columns.description: Hours of phone use while driving (0-2.2 hours)
columns.additional_information: Distracted driving metric, significant missing data (13.4%), no outliers detected

columns.name: highway_miles
columns.additional_information: Subset of total miles, moderate collision correlation (0.212), high outlier rate (12%)

columns.name: night_drive_hrs
columns.additional_information: Risk factor feature with low collision correlation (0.012), mostly zero values

columns.name: maximum_speed
columns.description: Maximum speed reached during month (60-90 mph)
columns.additional_information: Speed behavior metric with low collision correlation (0.063), constrained range

columns.name: collisions
columns.description: Number of collisions in the month (0, 1, or 2 collisions)
columns.additional_information: Target variable for multi-class classification with severe imbalance (95.2% class 0, 4.6% class 1, 0.2% class 2)

eda_summary: The telematic collision dataset presents a severely imbalanced multi-class classification problem with 95.2% no-collision cases. Key findings reveal that exposure metrics (miles driven, drive hours) are the strongest collision predictors, while driving behavior features (braking, acceleration, speeding) show weaker associations. Missing data is relatively low (1.53%) but concentrated in phone use feature (13.4%). The dataset requires careful preprocessing including handling class imbalance, feature scaling, and outlier treatment. The driver exposure hypothesis is supported by strong correlations between miles/hours and collision outcomes, suggesting that risk increases primarily with driving frequency rather than poor driving behavior.
task_summary_for_chat:
## 📊 EDA Complete - Vehicle Collision Prediction Analysis

I've completed a comprehensive exploratory data analysis of your telematic vehicle collision dataset. Here's what I discovered:

### 🚗 **Dataset Overview**
- **7,667 driver-month records** with 13 features
- **Multi-class target**: 0 (no collision), 1 (single), 2 (double collisions)
- **Severe class imbalance**: 95.2% no collisions, 4.6% single, 0.2% double

### 🔍 **Key Insights**

**📈 Exposure Matters Most**
- **Miles driven** is the strongest predictor (correlation: 0.297)
- Clear pattern: 425 miles (no collision) → 1,294 miles (1 collision) → 3,445 miles (2+ collisions)
- Risk increases with exposure, not necessarily poor driving behavior

**🎯 Data Quality**
- Overall good quality with only 1.53% missing values
- Phone use data has 13.4% missing (potential collection issues)
- Time speeding shows 17% outlier rate (measurement concerns)

**📊 Feature Patterns**
- Most features are right-skewed requiring transformation
- Driving behavior metrics (brakes, acceleration) moderately correlate with collisions
- Speed-related features show surprisingly weak associations

### 🚀 **ML Pipeline Recommendations**
1. **Address class imbalance** with SMOTE/stratified sampling
2. **Feature scaling** for numerical variables
3. **Target encoding** for high-cardinality driver_id
4. **Use PR-AUC metric** (ideal for imbalanced data)
5. **Ensemble methods** (Random Forest, XGBoost) recommended

### 📁 **Generated Files**
- **Interactive plots** (7 visualizations) in `/research/plots/`
- **Jupyter notebook** with complete analysis
- **JSON & Markdown reports** with detailed findings

The analysis suggests this is primarily an **exposure-based risk model** rather than a behavior-based one - drivers who drive more miles have higher collision rates, which makes intuitive sense for collision prediction modeling! 🎯
